If you are attaching wings on opposite sides this can happen (i.e you attach symmetrical wings on one side then flip your camera to the other side and attach symmetrical wings) If you stay on the same side of your aircraft when attaching parts this shouldn't be an issue.
Are you sure you're building your aircraft in the spaceplane hangar? You could definitely have this problem if you were building your plane in the VAB instead of the hangar.

the ones at the front go down while the ones at the back go up.

That's probably because they are on opposite side of the CoM.

Your controls are not "up down left right" - they're "pitch roll yaw throttle." Pressing "D" will try to pitch your craft up, which means the front goes up and the back goes down. The "wings" move accordingly to provide that turning force.

My guess would be you have too much drag forward of the center of mass due to the parachutes, or too much on the top. They tend to be far more stable if you put all intakes at the far back end, and balance the bottom and top drag with center of thrust.

If you have liftoff problems, I would move the gear to the end of the wings. Many of my planes crash into the runway if I do not do this, but fly well if I can lift off (a small roll due to SAS [automatic heading] correction becomes a large roll once stress on the landing gear becomes uneven.) If you are really sure it is balanced, try turning SAS off during takeoff... I have quite a few that will take off easily and without problem, but crash into the runway if I have SAS on.

You also have an unbalanced goo pod, which will cause roll. This is probably catastrophic due to the central landing gear.

EDIT: The wings going in different directions is expected, as they have control surfaces.

There are two buttons at the bottom you want to look at for wing placement, Center of Mass (CoM) and Center of Lift (CoL).

You usually want the center of mass to be slightly ahead of the center of lift, the higher the thrust to weight ratio (TWR), the further back the center of lift should be. If you put too much thrust on a plane you may want to consider building a rocket instead (or are going for orbital speed as in a single stage to orbit [sSTO]).

Jet engines are decent for small or medium size rockets too, just clamp the rocket down and let them spin up to full thrust before you release.
